forumNotes.author: Gildon7196
forumNotes.content: Say I have a windows 7 live cd I made with winbuilder. I put the cd into my computer which is completely blank. The hard drive is empty. I boot from the cd and now I have a live instance of Windows 7. With this live instance, am I able to download everything I want to download onto my hard drive and do stuff like play games such as Skyrim or something. Basically, is this live instance just like a normal computer. I understand that when I shut off the computer, the OS is no longer on the computer but it would seem all my downloads and games would be on my hard drive. So can I have a computer with pretty much full functionality that only works if you have the windows 7 live cd?

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> Say I have a windows 7 live cd I made with winbuilder. I put the cd into my computer which is completely blank. The hard drive is empty. I boot from the cd and now I have a live instance of Windows 7. With this live instance, am I able to download everything I want to download onto my hard drive and do stuff like play games such as Skyrim or something. Basically, is this live instance just like a normal computer. I understand that when I shut off the computer, the OS is no longer on the computer but it would seem all my downloads and games would be on my hard drive. So can I have a computer with pretty much full functionality that only works if you have the windows 7 live cd?

Yes.

Most probably you are NOT having a "windows 7 live cd", but rather a PE 3.x made out of Windows 7 sources (a PE is not a live Windows 7, it is a PE).

BUT there are THREE issues, one of probably no relevance, and one with big relevance.

1. The disk might be not "completely" empty anymore (you might not care about it, as - at the most could be the writing of the Disk Signature in the MBR and/or the MBR code itself written to it)
2. The system may "decide" to write on the internal disk a pagefile (this may happen or may not depending on a lot of possible settings/choices)
3. The system will be EXTREMELY slow unless you use a "RAM booted" PE (or mini-windows 7).

Since it doesn't really make sense to have a completely empty hard disk, issue #1 has only some relevance if the scope of the PE is "exact copy" or "forensics".

As well #2 is a relatively minor possible issue, if there is another Windows NT installed to the hard disk it may re-use the same pagefile.sys file, if there is not, let's say it is a all Linux machine the OS will probably reside on a EXT2/3/4 filesystem and the PE won't acces it at all, if the filesystem on the Hard Disk needs to be accessible to the PE (to save the downloaded files) then it's just a matter to configure properly the buiild.

The issue #3 is in fact the most relevant. a system using even partially the CD/DVD as "boot/system" volume will be slow as molasses.

So the point is making a system running entirely in RAM (and of course you need enough RAM to do that.

To be clear, once booted, you should be able to eject the CD/DVD and the system would still be fully functional.

And the initial loading will be anyway slow-slow, using a USB device (such as a stick/pendrive) will already be faster (and once fully loaded, a Ram based system will be blazingly fast).
